Welcome to pseudo’s documentation!¶

pseudocode interpreter

Writing actual code might be hard to understand for new-learners. Pseudocode is a tool for writing algorithms without knowing how to code. This module contains classes and methods for parsing pseudocode to AST and then evaluating it.

Example

If you installed this module with pip you can run pseudocode from file, i.e. to run test.pdc file type:

$ pseudo test.pdc

If you want to parse it by your own you will need pseudo.lexer.Lexer instance.:

from pseudo.lexer import Lexer

lex = Lexer("x := 12")

expression = lex.read_next()
print(expression)

If lexer reach the end of input, the parser.lexer.EndOfFile exception will be raised.

This module contains Lexer class using to tokenize stream.

class pseudo.lexer.Lexer(inp)¶

Class to parse code.

- i

A Stream instance with input code.

- keywords

A set of all keywords in pseudo.

- operators

A set of operators in pseudo.

- operator_keywords

A set of operators written as string.

- indent_size

Size of indentation using in particular file.

Usage: >>> lex = Lexer(“pisz 12”) >>> lex.read_next() Expression(“pisz”, args=[Number(12)])

is_alphabet(c) → bool¶

Checks if given char is from alphabet.

is_digit(c) → bool¶

Checks if given char is a digit.

is_keyword(string) → bool¶

Checks if given string is a keyword.

is_not_keyword_end(c) → bool¶

Checks if given char breaks parsing a keyword.

Example: asd1 - This is one keyword. asd1+asd2 - This is two keywords with + in between them.

is_operator(c) → bool¶

Checks if given char is an allowed operator.

read(test, eol=True) → str¶

Read an element of code from the stream based on given test function.

Parameters:
  • test – Function used to determine if next char should be included to expression.
  • eol – Optional variable, which switches end of line to be included to expression.
read_args(bracket: bool = None, indent_level: int = 0) → list¶

Read arguments from the stream.

read_bool(keyword: str) → pseudo.pseudo_types.Bool¶

Parse bool str to Bool object.

read_if(indent_level: int = 0) → object¶

Read condition of conditional expression.

read_indent(indent_level: int = 1) → list¶

Read indented expressions while valid indentation and returns list of them.

read_indent_size()¶

Read indent size from stream.

read_keyword() → str¶

Read a keyword from the stream.

read_next(prev: object = None, indent_level: int = 0) → object¶

Read next elements from the stream and guess the type.

read_number() → pseudo.pseudo_types.Int¶

Read a number from the stream.

read_string() → pseudo.pseudo_types.String¶

Read a string from the stream.

update_args(args, i)¶

Update args with new operation instance.

This module contains classes for types in AST.

class pseudo.pseudo_types.Assignment(target, value)¶

Node for representing assignments.

target¶

Target variable.

value¶

Value to assign.

class pseudo.pseudo_types.Bool(value)¶

Bool value node.

class pseudo.pseudo_types.Condition(condition, true, false=None)¶

Node for representing conditional expressions (if).

condition¶

Condtion to check

true¶

List to evaluate if condition is true

false¶

List to evaluate if condition is false (optional)

class pseudo.pseudo_types.EOL¶

Representation of newline.

class pseudo.pseudo_types.Int(value)¶

Int value node.

class pseudo.pseudo_types.Operation(operator, left, right)¶

Operation node.

class pseudo.pseudo_types.Operator(value)¶

Opartor class for representing mathematical operator.

class pseudo.pseudo_types.Statement(value, args=None)¶

Node for statement with arguments.

- value

Statement name.

- args

Arguments of statement.

class pseudo.pseudo_types.String(value)¶

String value node.

class pseudo.pseudo_types.Value(value)¶

Node containing a value.

value¶

Value of instance.

class pseudo.pseudo_types.Variable(value)¶

Node for representing variables.

- value

Name of the variable.

This module contains class of stream object used to iterate over input.

exception pseudo.stream.EndOfFile¶

Exception indicating that parsing ends.

class pseudo.stream.Stream(input: str)¶

Stream is an object used to iterate over input. It is a little bit similar to queue.

- input

List of lines of code.

- line

Number of current line. Counting from 1

- col

Number of current column. Counting from 1

eof() → bool¶

Returns true if next line is end of file and next char is end of line.

eol() → bool¶

Returns true if next char is end of line.

next() → str¶

Move cursor to next column and return char from this postion.

next_line()¶

Move cursor to next line.

peek(size: int = 0) → Union[str, pseudo.pseudo_types.EOL]¶

Returns next char without moving cursor. If next char does not exists it returns EOL instance.

Parameters:size (-) – Size of shift, default 0.
throw(error: str)¶

Used to display error messages with line number. It stops the execution.
